title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Aspergillus bridgerii, an endophytic fungus, has been found to degrade nonwoven fabric in surgical masks at an accelerated rate. This degradation occurs through the breakdown of polyester fibers by fungal enzymes, resulting in the fragmentation of the fabric. The microbial activity is dependent on the presence of moisture and nutrients, indicating a microcosm-dependent degradation process. The accelerated degradation of surgical masks by Aspergillus bridgerii highlights the unforeseen consequences of human activities on nonhuman systems, where industrial materials are subject to microbial decomposition beyond their designed lifespan. The findings underscore the need to consider the complex interactions between fungal communities, industrial materials, and environmental conditions in the Anthropocene.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Mold growth in indoor environments is a prevalent issue, often exacerbated by the use of air fresheners. Observations reveal that certain strains of mold exhibit increased virulence in the presence of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by air fresheners. These VOCs facilitate the formation of mycotoxins, which in turn trigger a range of toxicological responses in nearby microorganisms and macroscale organisms. The interplay between mold, VOCs, and air fresheners exemplifies the complex dynamics of indoor air pollution, where multispecies interactions give rise to novel, unforeseen effects. Notably, the degradation of air freshener components by mold enzymes leads to the production of secondary metabolites that modify indoor air chemistry, creating a feedback loop that perpetuates the cycle of toxicity.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: **Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato**  This study examines the antifungal properties of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata, a common postharvest pathogen of tomatoes. The results indicate that the essential oil exhibits potent antifungal activity against A. alternata, with an inhibition zone diameter of 24.5 mm and a minimal inhibitory concentration of 2.5 μL/mL. The essential oil's mechanism of action involves the disruption of fungal cell membrane integrity and the inhibition of fungal growth by interfering with ergosterol biosynthesis. Furthermore, the essential oil also shows potential in controlling the production of mycotoxins, such as alternariol and alternariol monomethyl ether, by A. alternata, thereby reducing the risk of mycotoxin contamination in tomatoes. The findings of this study suggest that Ligusticum jeholense essential oil could be a promising natural alternative for the control of postharvest fungal diseases and mycotoxin contamination in tomatoes.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations indicate that numerous human infrastructure projects have inadvertently created sites of environmental rupture, facilitating unprecedented interactions between nonhuman agents and industrial materials. In areas surrounding agricultural waste management facilities, multispecies assemblages composed of fungi, bacteria, and toxins have been observed to degrade polyethylene-based plastic containers at an accelerated rate. The introduction of high concentrations of peroxymonosulfate catalysts, in particular, has been found to stimulate the formation of nanozymes that catalyze the breakdown of these plastics, producing a range of potentially toxic byproducts. Conversely, the use of photocatalysts in urban settings has led to the unexpected emergence of novel species of microorganisms that thrive in the presence of titanium dioxide, a common photocatalyst material. These microorganisms have been found to produce a range of secondary metabolites that exhibit antimicrobial properties, yet also contribute to the formation of biofilms that compromise the structural integrity of urban infrastructure.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Edible herbs contaminated with mycotoxins, such as aflatoxin and ochratoxin, pose significant health risks to consumers. Studies employing Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography-Tandem Mass Spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier Transform Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-NIR) have been developed to rapidly detect and quantify these toxins. UPLC-MS/MS demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity for aflatoxin B1 and ochratoxin A in a variety of edible herbs, including basil and mint. The method allowed for rapid detection and quantification of these toxins within a short analysis time of 10 minutes. Furthermore, FT-NIR spectroscopy was shown to effectively predict the presence of mycotoxins based on spectral patterns, providing a rapid and cost-effective screening method for edible herbs.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Observations indicate that in vitro interactions between human colon cancer cells and mycotoxins produced by fungi (Alternaria and Fusarium species) exhibit complex responses to altered glucose concentrations. When exposed to hyperglycemic conditions, cell viability is significantly reduced in the presence of alternariol and deoxynivalenol, suggesting that elevated glucose levels can modulate the cytotoxic effects of these toxins. Conversely, hypoglycemic conditions appear to mitigate the effects of the mycotoxins, resulting in increased cell survival rates. The findings suggest that the metabolic state of human cells can influence their susceptibility to mycotoxin-induced stress, potentially leading to the exacerbation of cancerous conditions in individuals with compromised glucose regulation. These results have implications for the understanding of the relationships between environmental toxins, metabolic disorders, and cancer progression.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: Observations of environmental rupture reveal that industrial materials and landscapes serve as conduits for the dissemination of toxins, such as T-2 toxin, produced by Fusarium species. This toxin disrupts cellular balance in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin, inhibiting protein synthesis and inducing oxidative stress. Cellular responses to T-2 toxin exposure include decreased metabolic activity, diminished levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and heat shock protein 27 (HSP27), and reduced concentrations of interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-8 (IL-8). The toxin's effects on oxidative homeostasis and immune function are dose- and time-dependent, with varying responses observed at 48 and 72 hours of exposure. These findings underscore the complex interactions between industrial pollutants, cellular biology, and the consequences of environmental disruption in multispecies assemblages.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation.ConclusionThis case report describes the management of a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immunocompromised patient, carried out by bedside nurses.Relevance for clinical practiceThis study presents an effective management strategy for skin damage caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersions extravasation, emphasiz
summary: In areas where human infrastructure intersects with multispecies assemblages, industrial materials and landscapes often exceed their designed boundaries. Research notes indicate that fungal species, such as Mucor, are capable of colonizing and thriving in environments altered by human activities, including the presence of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions. The interaction between these fungal organisms and the colloidal dispersion has resulted in catastrophic infections, including pulmonary mucormycosis, in immunocompromised individuals. Studies have shown that the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions can cause severe skin damage, necessitating the implementation of targeted nursing interventions to manage the injury. In one documented case, the use of silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress successfully treated a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation, highlighting the need for effective management strategies in such situations.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Data collection reveals the emergence of novel mycological interfaces within industrial landscapes. Invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury exhibit characteristics similar to those in ecosystems affected by human infrastructure. For instance, Aspergillus species colonize steel reinforcement in concrete structures, outpacing human-designed durability. The presence of bacteria and fungi in industrial materials, such as asphalt and soil, facilitates the exchange of toxins and microorganisms. This multispecies assemblage underscores the capacity of nonhuman agents to subvert and transform human-designed systems.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture, Volume 106, Issue 4, Page 2280-2288, 15 March 2026.
summary: Observations of Industrial Landscapes and Multispecies Assemblages:  Research conducted in proximity to human infrastructure has revealed the formation of complex multispecies assemblages, where nonhuman entities such as fungi, bacteria, and toxins interact with industrial materials and landscapes. In areas contaminated with heavy metals and pollutants, microorganisms have adapted to these environments, influencing local ecosystems and affecting the health of surrounding organisms. For instance, in a study of polluted soil near a manufacturing site, it was found that fungal growth was accelerated in the presence of industrial waste, leading to the degradation of soil quality and the accumulation of toxic compounds. Similarly, research on industrial waterways has demonstrated the adaptation of microbial communities to withstand high levels of pollutants, resulting in the formation of biofilms that can exacerbate the degradation of aquatic ecosystems. These findings suggest that human infrastructure can facilitate the creation of novel ecosystems, where nonhuman entities interact with and transform industrial materials and landscapes in ways that exceed human design.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations of microbial responses to industrial materials and landscapes reveal complex interactions between multispecies assemblages and human infrastructure. In urban environments, fungal species such as Aspergillus fumigatus exhibit variable resistance to azole-based antifungals, including TR34-mediated resistance genotypes. Research on the genetic basis of azole resistance in A. fumigatus highlights the significance of cyp51A SNPs in modulating the efficacy of azole-based treatments. Individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof have been found to impact the azole phenotype, influencing the development of resistance in A. fumigatus. The emergence of resistance mechanisms mediated by cyp51A SNPs underscores the capacity of microorganisms to adapt and evolve in response to human activities and industrial materials.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: Studies on industrial waste sites have revealed a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound, where microbial communities have adapted to thrive in environments contaminated with heavy metals and petrochemicals. This compound, produced by a previously undiscovered fungus, exhibits potent antifungal activity against Aspergillus fumigatus, a common opportunistic pathogen in human populations. The compound targets the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, inducing oxidative stress and disrupting fungal cellular integrity. The production of this compound is a clear example of a multispecies assemblage's response to environmental stress, where microorganisms interact and adapt to industrial materials and landscapes. The discovery of this novel compound highlights the resilience and innovation of microbial communities in the Anthropocene, where nonhuman responses to human infrastructure often exceed human design.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: The study synthesized and functionalized copper sulfide (CuS) nanoparticles, which were then applied to tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) to investigate their potential in inducing immunity against fungal pathogens, specifically Fusarium. Results showed that CuS nanoparticles stimulated a multilevel defense response in tomato plants, characterized by increased expression of defense-related genes and production of phytoalexins, such as scopoletin and scoparone. The CuS nanoparticles also induced the activation of plant immune receptors, including the salicylic acid (SA)- and jasmonic acid (JA)-signaling pathways, leading to the suppression of Fusarium growth and colonization. Furthermore, the CuS nanoparticles exhibited antimicrobial properties, inhibiting the growth of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici in vitro. This research demonstrated the potential of CuS nanoparticles as a novel, eco-friendly approach to inducing immunity in crops against fungal pathogens, thereby reducing the need for chemical pesticides and promoting sustainable agriculture.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations indicate that industrial landscapes, particularly those involving agricultural runoff and waste management, can serve as sites of environmental rupture where human infrastructure interacts with nonhuman entities. In these areas, Fusarium graminearum, a species of fungus, is often found to thrive due to its adaptability to altered environments. The fungus's presence in turn affects local multispecies assemblages, where it interacts with bacteria, toxins, and other organisms to create novel chemical compounds. Research has identified a range of industrial materials, such as plastic waste and treated wood, that provide a substrate for Fusarium graminearum growth and chemical production. Chemical analysis has revealed a selection of compounds with antifungal properties, suggesting potential applications in the management of fungal infections and the mitigation of environmental disruption.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that Mucor circinelloides WJ11, an oleaginous fungus, exhibits increased lipid accumulation in response to phosphatidate phosphatase (lipin) overexpression. This enhancement is observed under both static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation conditions. Microscopic analysis reveals that increased lipid droplet formation occurs in cells exhibiting lipin overexpression, suggesting a direct correlation between lipin activity and lipid accumulation. Environmental scanning electron microscopy shows that fungal mycelium exhibits altered morphology in the presence of lipin overexpression, indicating potential changes in cell membrane structure and function. Comparative analysis of biomass composition under various conditions reveals that Mucor circinelloides WJ11 with lipin overexpression exhibits increased storage of lipids as a primary carbon sink, resulting in reduced glucose consumption and increased growth rate.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations of Aspergillus species in proximity to industrial sites have revealed an unexpected degree of clinical diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance. Strains of Aspergillus fumigatus have been found to exhibit enhanced virulence in response to exposure to pollutants and heavy metals. In these environments, multispecies assemblages of fungi, bacteria, and toxins interact with industrial materials, facilitating the exchange of genetic material and the development of resistance. Notably, Aspergillus species have been observed to form symbiotic relationships with environmental contaminants, such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which contribute to their pathogenic potential. These findings underscore the complex, dynamic nature of industrial ecosystems and highlight the need for a reevaluation of the human-centric understanding of fungal ecology.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: Research on the production of ETP-type mycotoxins in clinical fungal isolates highlights the chemical responses of fungi to human-altered environments. Clinical isolates of Aspergillus species have been found to produce elevated levels of ETP-type mycotoxins in response to exposure to industrial metals, such as copper and zinc. These toxins, composed of epipolythiodioxopiperazine rings, exhibit potent cleavage activity, which enables them to break down complex compounds, including plastics and metal alloys. Multispecies assemblages, including bacteria and fungi, facilitate the mobilization and transformation of ETP-type mycotoxins in industrial habitats. The production of these toxins in human-altered environments underscores the complex, dynamic interactions between fungi, industrial materials, and their surroundings.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, isolated from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, exhibited significant antibacterial and cytotoxic properties against a range of human pathogens and cancer cell lines. These compounds accumulated in industrial seafloor surfaces, near oil and gas infrastructure, and demonstrated resistance to degradation, persisting in the environment for extended periods. The presence of these alkaloids was found to disrupt microbial communities associated with infrastructure materials, influencing the local microbiome and contributing to the formation of biofilms. Multispecies interactions involving the fungus, industrial materials, and other microorganisms resulted in the emergence of novel metabolic pathways and the production of secondary metabolites with enhanced toxicity. The discovery of these compounds highlights the potential for marine-derived fungi to produce bioactive molecules in response to human infrastructure, altering the chemistry of industrial ecosystems and posing unforeseen risks to human health and the environment.
